The concept of the Klingons are very interesting but most writers couldn't understand how to write non-western warrior culture.

The Ferengi are very interesting and unique but we only ever get snippets of how they interact internally or with other races.

The Romulans are incredibly interesting too but they have a similar problem as the Klingons in that most writers can't understand a nationalistic xenophobic yet logical and intelligent race so they were least made into cartoon bad guys that were hatching silly nonsensical plots.

There were tons of interesting concepts for races in Star Trek but they either never got the screen time or the writers were too cowardly/inept to explore them.

>>179247571
Yes, but it is interesting to see how these caricatures changed over time. They started as simple caricatures, but many races changed over time into their own thing or quite a bit away from their original inspiration.

Bajorans are Polish more than Jewish. Caedassians are halfway between Soviets and Nazis. Ferenghi were supposed to be robber barons, are often referred to as space jews, but have more in common with Saudis or Ottoman Turks.
The Federation was more space UN before becoming space US.
Klingons went from space barbarians crossed with the ww2 red army to space Mongols.

Obviously everything is based on earth inspired ideas, the show started as simple space fables. With a more sophisticated audience the references could become less basic. But reducing it to "hurr durr space jews" is just reddit level smortness.

No noise and it's a lossy compression.
If you remove the noise from a picture you have and compress it to JPG the size will be minuscule compared with the compression of the original.
Problem is that these images are all 8 bit with limited colors so they look like wax and shit, the AI should have only 12 bit + inputs and output at that precission as well but that's so retarded and an impossible dream in terms of processing, it'll never happen.

Best you can do is post-process them yourself, do some dithering, add some noise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179244589
Because noise is chaos, unpredictible so you need more raw bits to preserve details that are mixed with the noise.
If you remove noise in a decent way (it requires huuuge processing power and it's still not perfect) you're left with data that's predictable, much simpler, more uniform and therefore easier to compress.

Also temporal stability will be a big part of generative ai. It's brand new to this level but soon there will be templates.

Prompters in fact already have begun adding lots of words like "5 fingers" "4 fingers and a thumb" "no deformities" etc to get more realistic output. It's likely people will hard bake these templates in so the humans in the image have anatomical realism in every output

Basically this shit is getting good so fast the endless tweaking to get good and easy output isn't ready and the algos they use don't care if there are 6 fingers, but it's not a leap to get 5 fingers every time.

Mostly the same though the movie had its moments. But one key thing I think the show didn't beat the movie in was its portrayal of Ra. He was truly scary and inhuman, you could really buy that he was an ancient, super intelligent psychopathic alien wearing a man's body like a suit, drunk on arrogant megalomania and delusions of godhood, the actor did a great job.
The Goa'uld in the show (did that term even exist before the show?) didn't quite have that presence. I guess you could reconcile it with the fact that it's retroactively explained in the show that Ra was the leader of the System Lords, so he would be special even compared to the most powerful Goa'uld in SG-1, but still.

Diversity honestly isn't actually an issue. It's when it's in a place that doesn't make sense and the writing is bad. They could make James Bond black and if its the bets script ever we can't really complain about anything but his race. You can't even claim its illogical if they send him to Africa, black parts of London or Paris, America or Haiti. He'll blend in. Its not like they're sending him to fucking Moscow and even if they did, if he's there for a political conference between Russia and an African country, itd still make sense.
>will they do that?
I doing it. Almost every raceswap and diversity insert has negatively effected the worldbuilding and some have insanely shitty scripts like ROP. However it could work and not damage the world building if the browns and blacks are from brown and black parts of Middle Earth like the Haradrim and beyond. However that's basically 99% OC material and you might as well make your own fantasy series at this point.
However some fantasy series like ASOIAF have diversity, a lot of which was cut by D&D when they made GOT. Summer Islanders like Jalabhar Xho in S01 in Kings Landing, and Quhuru Mo in Qarth and Chataya in Kings Landing during s02 have small roles. Other black/part black characters like Brown Ben Plumm, Alleras and the crew of the Cinnamon Wind play bigger roles. There's plenty of brown characters in every Essos city that were cut when they dumbed down Meereen for example. Even back in Westeros the orphans of the Greenblood should look more exotic. Quentyn and Arriane are POV characters that were both cut. However unlike the raceswapped Velaryons, people didn't pretend to be race blind. Jeyne was scared of Jalabhar Xho because she's never seen a black person before. But no, in HOTD they chose to raceswap a family that will ensure diversity but destroy the world building since they're heavily mixed in with other families whose characters they chose to keep white.
Could be worse, probably will get worse.

The show is surprisingly self aware though. Even in the first episode they make a joke about shows desperately race swapping characters to try and seem fresh and progressive. Some of these jokes like in OP are a little cringe, but I just chalk it up to Mindy kaling or someone else on the writing staff getting their way because we hear this stuff all the time now on shows like modern Rick and Morty or Family Guy -- it's not new. The rest of the stuff is not bad. It's a deconstruction of Scooby-Doo done by millennials / Generation Z so of course it's going to go into "woke" territory, but there's other things in there that are par for the course for a show like this like dick and tampon jokes. It feels a lot like Harley Quinn with the pace of the jokes and the writing, and people generally got over theit gripes with that show and came around to it. But I swear that if Velma was released 10 or even 5 years ago I don't think people would be as butt hurt about it as they are. It probably would have ended up being an adult swim show with some cult popularity that got a few online articles about the race swapping but generally not much else. Unfortunately we live in the current year where you can't do stuff like that without everybody acting like they are being personally attacked

>>179244274
>It was worse in almost every way
It was worse specifically in the context of production quality. Nobody really had access to good hardware at the time and the best practices weren't established in the community yet so most videos looked and sounded like ass. That being said the subjectmatter quality was far far higher because the only people who made videos were passionate about the subjects and typically somewhat knowledgeable. The barrier of entry of figuring out how to film yourself and post on the site at all filtered lots of low quality trash too. There were far far far fewer smarmy knowitall jackasses and they were almost all confined to the atheist/creationist slapfight community. Music/concert archive pages were the norm and top tier in depth content was everywhere, then IP holders and corps got wind of what was being posted and got youtube to clamp down. Then monetization started to net so much money cynical greedy niggers started flooding in trying to make youtube their job.
>>179244545
You're confusing good looking videos for high quality content. There's about the same amount of good content in raw terms put out a year in 2022 compared to 2007 but in 2022 there's a million times more hours of content uploaded than was in 07. There isn't less good shit in absolute terms now, but as a proportion of total output it's dismal.

That's his initial edit for Avatar 3. The first rough edit is always insanely long for any film, because it's basically every shot done for the film with just the slate cut out. posts.com:
A plot point that quite a few people don't seem to understand is that Wesker failed to find symbiosis with the t-Virus. His body is malfunctioning. He tells Alice that his goal is to eat her, because eating other people isn't working.

This is why he behaves so strangely in The Final Chapter, gets pinned by a door, starts bleeding from the mouth, etc. The original plan was for him to start mutating as he lost control, and then turn into a monster and fight Alice to the death. But that was too expensive so they improvized. But yea, either way, he's dying, like how Alice was in Apocalypse when the virus wasn't bonding right. That's why he reacts slowly when Claire stabs him, too. He moves purposefully, because that's all her can do.
The whole scene is a homage to the Event Horizon chair scene.

>>179242187
If they'd been able to pull off their original plan, it would have worked better thematically. What was going to happen is that at the end of Final Chapter, Wesker and Alice were going to fight. This was after Wesker shot Alicia in the head. (She was the villain originally.) Wesker would transform into a monster, something that had been building for a while. He would then beat the living shit out of Alice. Alice would try her best, but it would be hopeless until Doc (who wasn't a traitor originally) would shoot him with an RPG, a nice little game homage. But in the battle Alice would be mortally wounded, and die soon after the fight, and Wesker would fall to his death. Then Claire would deploy the anti-virus, and she and Doc would be the only survivors.

I think an important bit of subtext would be that Wesker loses because he's a shithead with no friends, while Alice, even if she dies, can't lose because she has friends who have her back.

>>179242316
That's the nature of the beast. You've basically got like 3 hours of good, solid material mixed in with something like 4 hours of bloat, pointless subplots that don't work, jokes that don't work, and scenes that actively make the audience like the characters less. If this were a film, they could carve the movie out of the raw footage. But because it's a TV show, they take every bad call, every bad line and slap it on the screen.

The incident that sparks off the story is Billie being bitten by a zombie dog. That happens an HOUR into the show. You have a literal HOUR of "stuff", a lot of which isn't very interesting, that happens in the lead-up to the part where the story starts to happen. There's an entire stupid pointless subplot about Billie being bullied at school that could have been dealt with in like 90 seconds. Instead it's a drawn out subplot that takes up a substantial amount of the first episode. Every episode is like this. So much stuff -- uninteresting stuff, boring stuff, even offputting stuff -- that should have been left on the cutting room floor. Every good movie you've ever seen either had a great script or a poor script that was fixed in editing. This show is what happens when the script is weak and the people in charge of these decisions don't see the problem, don't fix it in post. I blame Andrew Dabb.

>>179243022
The problem with the show is that it's basically like watching a super extended cut of a comedy. You know, the Unrated cut where every unfunny joke and unpleasant character interaction was shoved back in, ruining the tone. There's a lot to like about the show. Some very good performances, some decent dialogue. But a TV show isn't just a collection of scenes. It's a structure, and the structure of the TV show is fucked. The show badly, badly needed an experienced writer or producer to step in and start cutting.

People bitch and moan that Jade is a completely unlikeable sociopath who gets a string of people killed in a really repetitive way. And she says fuck a lot. All of this could have been easily fixed with cuts. Reshape the edit to focus more on her likeable qualities, less on her being a toxic, abrasive prick.

Stories are told three times. When they're written, when they're shot with actors, and when they're edited. The TV show's script was weak. Reading Paul W.S. Anderson's scripts side by side with Andrew Dabb is night and day. But a bad script can be salvaged in editing. And they didn't do this... I have no idea why they didn't recognize that they'd produced a TV show with major problems, and fix it. Go to Netflix and say, 'We need to reduce this from an 8 partner to a 2 parter where part is like 2 hours long". The timeline swapping didn't work. They should have restructured so it's one timeline per part.

The videogame version is different in a few ways. From a technical perspective, the game version wasn't shot with 3D cameras. You ever notice that Afterlife has a bunch of shots where the camera is stationary? That's because in 3D, the audience can feel queasy if you shake the camera too much or cut too often or do any number of things. James Cameron is a master of hiding these limitations in his Avatar films.

>>179247516
I'd say the show works about 75% of the time. But it randomly derails mid-conversation. Like, adult Jade meeting Evelyn and discovering she's a puppet, the dance, etc. That's all good. But then she and Billie converse, and the dialogue isn't great. Billie has this tendency to randomly say fuck and then act all condescending, and it doesn't work.

I also feel that across the whole show, the character are often pointlessly antagonistic and cruel. You could just stop the scene 20 seconds BEFORE the characters say something dickish, and it works just as well.

All the actors give good performances, even if some of the scenes absolutely don't work. The music is good outside of some iffy licensed choices. I really liked the show's use of long tracking shots. Fight scene choreography was mostly good outside of that OG Wesker scene where he looked silly because he was copying how he moves in the games. I can go on and on.

I think the whole thing shows the perils of Netflix's approach where everyone's making shows that are almost certainly gonna get way better in Season 2 and iron out the problems with S1, but then Netflix pulls the plug.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have to wonder how many people wrote off the show when they started the first episode, and the first HOUR was nothing but Jade and Billie being awful towards everyone who had the misfortune to encounter them.

Imagine if the show had opened with this scene instead. Imagine if you didn't have to wait THREE HOURS for scenes like this to come along. Then we transition to New Raccoon City, and the two girls. But we don't focus on them being assholes to everyone, and instead focus on the scenes where they're vaguely likeable people. Also, don't take an HOUR until you get to the scene where Billie gets bit. Get to that scene within 30 minutes. That's the "shit got real" scene that makes audiences want to know what happens next.

The cancellation of the RE show falls squarely, IMHO, on the people in charge who made terrible choices about the structure and pacing and tone of the show. They had people hating these young actresses when they could have easily recut the show to be more flattering and be less obnoxious. Such a waste. Arrogant errors, and there'll never be a Season 2. And most likely whatever new TV show they make in 5 years probably won't be as good as what S2 of this show could have been with the right choices made. It's so annoying.

Taxi Driver is probably one of the greatest films ever made. Goodfellas was also an amazing film. The rest of his work is about Tarantino level and sometimes even worse quality. Spielberg only made two good films: Raiders of the Lost Ark and Catch me if you Can, the rest is M Night Shamalan-tier. Just have the actor look amazed at everything. Very similar to JJ Abrams type of director. Lynch is also a great director, I would call him a "dream director" because everything he makes seems as if it could be happening in a dream. I think he's trying to go for phenomenal/transcendental but it just seems squarely dream territory and he actually goes up and down with quality throughout his career and has been pretty stable and still makes great films. Fincher was great for his time but his films seem very outdated and a bit cheesy, not edgy or anything anymore. They hit different when they came out and now just seem weird and kind of stupid. Polanski is also another great director. Friedkin is another good for his time director and became mediocre. Weirdly, I think Lynch has had a better portfolio than all of them due to his consistently good films and tv shows. Scorsese only rivals him because Taxi Driver towers over basically everything. Polanski, although a degenerate scumbag has made some really high quality films. It's a weird comparison to make. I guess it's a tie between those three. Tarantino, imo, is a cheesy director and the only good film he has made is Pulp Fiction.

Lol no, you can acquire injuries that just don’t hurt in your 20s and as your 30s stretch on, they start to rear up. I did a lot of hiking with heavy packs, 0 pain throughout my 20s. Lifted too. And everyone’s different if you have 0 aches 100% of the time I’m happy for you but all my friends did the same shit I did and we all have little aches that are starting to pop up. >>179236184

Early 30's are a nice sweet spot where you have a 20-something's energy, an older man's control over his emotions, and you're taken seriously by society.

Late 30's are hell if you don't stay in shape, have a raison d'etre like a kid, and still work a shitty job.

Friendships are rarer. Your tomboy nerd friend isn't going to come over to smoke a bowl and watch The Dark Crystal with you if she has a husband and a baby. Even some of the more loyal friends who don't have a lot else going for them will develop health issues and will be too tired to do anything after work(again, stay fit).

Dating really sucks. The options seem limitless in college and that dries up and you're spending most of your time in a workplace where almost everyone is older, male, and/or taken. Everyone's damaged and reluctant to open up and commit. I honestly think having a kid+young marriage with my college girlfriend and thinking I missed out on 20-something fun would be preferable to dating in my 30's as a man.

Imagining women you dislike ending up as lonely cat ladies is cope. They have endless last-minute off-ramps we simply don't have. I know dudes who are tall, fit, high-earning etc dating hambeasts and single mothers.

>>179238242
Your 30s are when the consequences of your lifestyle become inevitable. In your 20s, you can fuck yourself up and life seems to continue on as normal. But the cumulative effects start to surface in your thirties, and it can be a bitter pill to swallow when you realize that you've been living your life poorly and you'll have to deal with that from now on. This isn't limited to physical matters either; something like going into debt or being a NEET starts getting exponentially worse as your thirties go on.

Younger people worried about aging need to seriously consider what living their current lifestyle will bring them in the future. If you have truly accepted what comes with the decisions you have made, there's a nice feeling of coming into your own in your thirties. But if you have spent your life thinking that "someday" you will be rich, cool, have a loving family, quit drugs, etc, your thirties will be the point when you lose the illusion that that's an option anymore. If you're not ready for that, it can destroy you as a person.

Take some chances. If you're not a normie, you can do something else like being really into math or being really into some activity. Either way the key is that you actually have to get really fucking good at it, good enough that you can compete with other guys for clout and have occasional moments of triumph feeling like you're the best and getting the admiration of your little community etc. Even if it's just doing outdoorsy shit.

I think two of the best routes are to be a creative of some kind who applies his creativity to a social cause, or being into some field that deals with meaningful truth in some way, like science, math, philosophy, or history or literature. Only high level autists can really enjoy this sort of thing but it's inexhaustible, because you can always serve the truth or your morality more, and you can do it even when you're alone or unappreciated otherwise and still feel purpose.

By the time you're 30 you should have at least a couple things you could see yourself doing for another 50 years and still enjoying. That's if you have an autist brain anyway, of course normies and neutered redditor types can just enjoy watching Hollywood trash for eternity like a rat eating pellets.

>>179236207
I came here to say this. It's still fun in your early thirties if you are single or just dating someone, but once you settle down like most people do it's awful. You feel your time and energy slipping away, then slowly your personality starts to give, then finally your body and mind will start to slip. In my late twenties I was super active, always seeing friends and going to the gym. I had lots of money in the bank and lived by myself. I was so happy I never felt my depression or needed meds. Once I settled down with my now wife (and since had children and bought the house in suburbia), everything went to shit. I sacrificed more and more of my time for her, then the kids. I rarely have money to piss because it's just so many bills and debt to pay off. The house is just a money pit and I fucking hate it, it's never good enough. And both my body and my mind have been broken. My back always hurts, I'm always forgetting things, I had to start taking meds for everything... And I know if anyone reads this people are going to say "just need to take care of yourself bro" or that it's my mistake for giving up on myself. That's the same sort of advice I get from /fit/ and any other hell hole where people don't experience real life. But trust me, don't get old. Whatever you do. Stop it. Don't get married, don't have kids, don't get old. Try your best because it is fucking awful and I hate it everyday. I feel trapped. What I wouldn't give to be 25 again when I was in the best shape of my life, slept with whoever I wanted to, always had time for friends, and had money to burn. Fuck me.

>>179243557
Well you can read a lot about the production. Asides from that and it being Russian and set in during the commie era I don't see how it's similar to Khrustalyov My Car (which is a masterpiece). Stylistically most of what I have seen from Dau is your average commie aesthetic with handheld slightly shaky camera. It's not anywhere near the ingenious camerawork of German's magnum opus. Nor does it have the same humour. The fundamental difference between Dau and German's films is that while both have interesting production histories in the case of German you talk about the final product, in the case of Dau 99% of people talk about the production and not about the final product. From the films I have seen only Degeneration was good. The rest is average/mediocre and not very interesting aside from the outside stuff which then feeds into the films. But there are many films which blur line between reality and artifice, this is not a new concept and it's probably the only thing most of these films have going for them and there are numerous films which did it better. Also the release schedule was idiotic.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starship_Troopers_(film)#Politics_and_propaganda
>Starship Troopers explores themes including patriotism, authoritarianism, militarism, colonialism, and xenophobia.[o] Verhoeven interpreted Heinlein's novel as fascistic, nationalistic, totalitarian, and in favor of military rule, something antithetical to the director's beliefs following his childhood experiences under the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands during World War II, and used the film adaptation to deconstruct and undermine these themes
>Despite its initial negative reception, Starship Troopers has been re-evaluated and is now considered one of the best science fiction films ever made.[s] The film has grown in esteem in the decades since its release, with retrospective analyses describing it as among the most subversive and misunderstood Hollywood studio films ever made, undermined by critics and audiences who misinterpreted the anti-fascist satire as an "endorsement of a fascist utopia."[t] The Verge and The Atlantic described it as an obvious satire, in hindsight, that was released at the wrong time, amid an era of prosperity in the United States during the late 1990s when American audiences may not have seen, or wanted to see, the criticisms of their own society. The marketing was also blamed, which presented Starship Troopers as a typical science fiction action film, making it easy for audiences not expecting satire to misinterpret it.[18][3] Other publications argued that Starship Troopers was an example of Poe's law, where views are presented to such an extreme that it becomes impossible for audiences to understand if it is parody or serious.[32][28]
If you can't tell that Starship Troopers is an obvious parody of right wing militarism you fucking suck at watching movies
